questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Dimetrodon is a large, extinct, cold-blooded, carnivorous reptile (see figure below). Fossils show that Dimetrodon had fixed spines extending from its vertebrae that, when covered with skin, formed a large sail. Two scientists discuss the sail's function.


Scientist 1
The sail helped regulate body temperature. Dimetrodon needed to warm its body to the activity temperature, the temperature at which it was active enough to hunt. This could be achieved most rapidly by turning the broad side of the sail toward the morning sun. A mathematical model shows that a reptile with a sail would reach the activity temperature 3 times faster than a reptile without a sail. Rapid warming gave Dimetrodon a distinct advantage catching cold-blooded prey.

Grooves on the sail's spines held large blood vessels. Regulating the blood flow through these vessels during the heat of the day allowed the reptile to radiate heat away from its body and prevent overheating.

Four other cold-blooded reptile species from this same time and climate also had bony projections or sails on their back. Today, elephants regulate their body temperature by flapping their large ears.

Scientist 2
The sail was used for display. First, the sail made the reptile appear larger, thereby discouraging attacks from predators. Second, sails were smaller in female Dimetrodons than in males, indicating the sails were used by the males for attracting mates. Modern lizards change their skin color and pattern to attract a mate. Similarly, Dimetrodons controlled the appearance of the skin on the sail by regulating the blood supply to the sail.

Sphenacodon is a cold-blooded reptile that lived at the same time and in the same climate as Dimetrodon. Sphenacodon is a close relative of Dimetrodon and is identical in all details of its anatomy, except that it did not have a sail or any other projections on its back. If sails were needed for temperature regulation, Sphenacodon would have had one also.

Mathematical calculations show that as a Dimetrodon sail absorbed heat on the side facing the sun, it may have lost nearly as much heat from the side facing away from the sun.
questions.question: 1.  According to the mathematical calculations mentioned by Scientist 2, a Dimetrodon that turned its sail toward the morning sun would experience:

choices.A: rapid overheating and death.
choices.B: little or no increase in body temperature.
choices.C: an increase in the length of the sail spines.
choices.D: a decrease in the blood supply to the sail.

questions.question: 2.  If Scientist 1 is correct, exposing its sail to a strong wind would have which of the following effects on a Dimetrodon's body temperature? Exposing its sail to a wind at a temperature less than the body temperature of Dimetrodon would:

choices.A: warm the sail and lower the body temperature.
choices.B: warm the sail and raise the body temperature.
choices.C: remove heat from the sail and lower the body temperature.
choices.D: remove heat from the sail and raise the body temperature.

questions.question: 3.  According.to Scientist 2, male Dimetrodons would control the blood supply to their sails in order to:

choices.A: increase or decrease the spines' width.
choices.B: reduce their body temperature.
choices.C: change the sails' color or pattern.
choices.D: raise or lower their sails.

questions.question: 4.  Both scientists would most likely agree with which of the following statements about Dimetrodons and modern animals?

choices.A: There are similarities between Dimetrodons and some modern animals.
choices.B: There are no similarities between Dimetrodons and any modern animals.
choices.C: There are no modern animals that are direct or indirect descendants of Dimetrodons.
choices.D: There are many modern animals that look exactly like Dimetrodons.

questions.question: 5.  According to Scientist 1, a cold-blooded, carnivorous reptile without a sail would have compared to a Dimetrodon of the same size in which of the following ways? This reptile without a sail would have:

choices.A: reached the activity temperature more slowly than did Dimetrodon.
choices.B: reached the activity temperature more quickly than did Dimetrodon.
choices.C: been much easier to see than was Dimetrodon.
choices.D: been less easily preyed upon than was Dimetrodon.

questions.question: 6.  Both scientists would most likely agree with which of the following statements about Dimetrodons and their sails? Dimetrodons were able to:

choices.A: raise and lower their sails at will.
choices.B: shed and regrow their sails periodically.
choices.C: control the blood supply to their sails.
choices.D: regulate body temperature without their sails.

questions.article:

questions.question: 7.  Based on the information in Scientist 1's viewpoint, which of the following figures best represents how a Dimetrodon would orient its sail with respect to the sun in order to minimize heating during late afternoon?

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
The rate of a chemical reaction can be measured as the change in the concentration of its products over a period of time. The following experiments were performed to investigate factors that influence the rate at which potassium permanganate (KMnO4) reacts with oxalic acid（H2C2O4) to form Mn2+and other products.

Experiment 1
A 4.0 mL sample of 0.1 M (moles/liter) aqueous KMnO4, which was purple in color, was measured with a clean graduated cylinder and poured into a test tube. A 4.0 mL sample of 1.0 M aqueous H2C2O4 was then measured with a clean graduated cylinder and poured into a second test tube. The 2 test tubes were placed in a 25℃ water bath. After 5 minutes the H2C2O4 solution was mixed with the KMnO4 solution and placed back in the water bath. The time until the purple color disappeared was recorded. This procedure was repeated at 3 other temperatures. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The procedure from Experiment 1 was repeated in every way except that 0.1 mg of manganous sulfate（MnSO4), a catalyst, was added to each test tube containing KMnO4 before the H2C2O4 was added. Catalysts are substances that increase the rate of reactions without being used up. The results are shown in Table 2.


Experiment 3
The procedure from Experiment 1 was repeated at a constant temperature of 25°C and various concentrations of H2C2O4. The results are shown in Table 3.
questions.question: 8.  In Experiment 1, as the reaction temperature increased, the time until the purple color disappeared:

choices.A: remained the same.
choices.B: decreased only.
choices.C: increased only.
choices.D: increased, then decreased.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:

After 5 minutes the H2C2O4 solution was mixed with the KMnO4 solution and placed back in the water bath. The time until the purple color disappeared was recorded. This procedure was repeated at 3 other temperatures. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The procedure from Experiment 1 was repeated in every way except that 0.1 mg of manganous sulfate（MnSO4), a catalyst, was added to each test tube containing KMnO4 before the H2C2O4 was added. Catalysts are substances that increase the rate of reactions without being used up. The results are shown in Table 2.


Experiment 3
The procedure from Experiment 1 was repeated at a constant temperature of 25°C and various concentrations of H2C2O4. The results are shown in Table 3.
questions.question: 9. If the procedure described in Experiment 2 was repeated and a reaction time of 6 sec was measured, the temperature of the reaction was most likely:

choices.A: less than 25°C.
choices.B: greater than 25°C and less than 40°C.
choices.C: greater than 40℃ and less than 55°C.
choices.D: greater than 55°C.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:

Experiment 3

questions.question: 10.  How is the experimental design of Experiment 1 different from that of Experiment 2? In Experiment 1:

choices.A: MnSO4 was not added to the reaction; in Experiment 2 MnSO4 was added.
choices.B: the concentration of KMnO4 was less than that used in Experiment 2.
choices.C: reaction temperatures were varied; in Experiment 2 they remained constant.
choices.D: the concentration of H2C2O4 was varied; in Experiment 2 it remained constant.

questions.question: 11.  Each of the following factors was investigated in the experiments EXCEPT:

choices.A: adding a catalyst to the reaction mixture.
choices.B: changing the reaction solvent.
choices.C: varying the reaction temperature.
choices.D: changing the concentration of a reactant.

questions.question: 12.  A student performed the procedure described in Experiment 1, mixing an H2C2O4 solution at 45°C with a KMnO4 solution at 40°C. Based on the results of Experiment 1, the reaction time was most likely:

choices.A: less than 25 sec.
choices.B: greater than 25 sec and less than 48 sec.
choices.C: greater than 48 sec and less than 105 sec.
choices.D: greater than 105 sec.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:

questions.question: 13. A student repeating Trial 9 unknowingly used a graduated cylinder that already contained 1.0 mL of H2O to measure the H2C2O4 solution. Based on the results of Experiment 3, the reaction time that she measured was most likely:

choices.A: less than 415 sec.
choices.B: greater than 415 sec and less than or equal to 625 sec.
choices.C: greater than 625 sec and less than or equal to 837 sec.
choices.D: greater than 837 sec.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
As a living cell's surface area-to-volume ratio (S/V) increases, so does the cell's ability to exchange substances with its environment.

To model this exchange process, different-sized cubes of gelatin were immersed in a dye for 1 minute. Table 1 lists the edge length, surface area, volume, S/V, and per-cent volume of gelatin that was dyed.


Figure 1 shows the S/V of certain rectangular solids and spheres.


Figure 2 shows the volume of certain rectangular solids and spheres as a function of surface area.


Table 2 lists the diameter and surface area of 5 types of spherical ova (egg cells).


Table 2 adapted from Norman K. Wessells and Janet L. Hopson, Biology. ©1988 by Random House, Inc.
questions.question: 14.  Ova with very large volumes tend to contain large amounts of nutrients that are used for growth by the embryo. Based on the information in Table 2 andFigure 2, which of the following ova most likely contain the greatest amount of nutrients?

choices.A: Sea urchin ova
choices.B: Human ova
choices.C: Hummingbird ova
choices.D: Hen ova

choices.A: 20mm
choices.B: 40mm
choices.C: 60mm
choices.D: 80mm

choices.A: The units for volume are mm and the units for surface area are mm2.
choices.B: The units for volume are mm2 and the units for surface area are mm3.
choices.C: The units for surface area are mm and the units for volume are mm2.
choices.D: The units for surface area are mm2 and the units for volume are mm3.

Table 2 adapted from Norman K. Wessells and Janet L. Hopson, Biology. ©1988 by Random House, Inc.
questions.question: 17.  Based on the information in Figure 1, a spherical cell with a diameter of 6 mm will have an S/V closest to which of the following values?

choices.B: 1 mm-1
choices.C: 2 mm-1

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
As a living cell's surface area-to-volume ratio (S/V) increases, so does the cell's ability to exchange substances with its environment.

To model this exchange process, different-sized cubes of gelatin were immersed in a dye for 1 minute. Table 1 lists the edge length, surface area, volume, S/V, and per-cent volume of gelatin that was dyed.


Figure 1 shows the S/V of certain rectangular solids and spheres.


Figure 2 shows the volume of certain rectangular solids and spheres as a function of surface area.


Table 2 lists the diameter and surface area of 5 types of spherical ova (egg cells).


Table 2 adapted from Norman K. Wessells and Janet L. Hopson, Biology. ©1988 by Random House, Inc.
questions.question: 18.  Based on the information in Table 1, if a cube-shaped plant cell had an edge length of 0. 5 mm, it would have an S/V of:

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Some students were interested in why antifreeze is mixed with the H2O in a car's radiator. They knew that when a substance is dissolved in H2O, the boiling points are elevated and the freezing points are lowered relative to H2O. They performed the following experiments to investigate the effects of the addition of ethylene glycol (C2H6O2), the active ingredient in most types of antifreeze, to H2O.

Experiment 1
Six solutions of various concentrations of C2H6O2 in H2O were prepared. The mass of 10.00 mL of each solution was measured, and the density of each solution was calculated using the following formula:


The densities of 100% H2O and 100% C2H6O2 were also determined. The students found that as the concentration of C2H6O2 increased, the density of the solution increased.

Experiment 2
A 20 mL sample of H2O was placed in a flask containing a thermometer and the flask was heated. The temperature at which the H2O first started to boil was recorded as the boiling point. This procedure was repeated with C2H6O2 and the solutions prepared in Experiment 1 (see Figure 1).


Experiment 3
A 90 g sample of H2O (freezing point = 0℃) and 10 g of C2H6O2 (freezing point = -11. 5°C) were placed in a cup containing a thermometer. The mixture was stirred as it was cooled in a low-temperature bath. The temperature at which ice crystals first began to appear was recorded as the freezing point. The procedure was repeated with different amounts of H2O and C2H6O2 (see Table 1) .
questions.question: 19.  If Experiment 2 were repeated with an aqueous solution containing 80% C2H6O2 by mass, the boiling point of the solution would most likely be:

choices.A: less than 100℃.
choices.B: between 100°C and 110°C.
choices.C: between 110°C and 115°C.
choices.D: greater than 115°C.

questions.question: 20.  Where the students live, the lowest temperature during the past year was -31°C. Based on the results of Experiment 3, which of the following percents, by mass, of C2H6O2 in H2O would have been necessary to be sure that the mixtures in car radiators in this area did not freeze?

questions.question: 22.  A student repeating Experiment 3 placed an aqueous mixture containing 65% C2H6O2 in the low-temperature bath. She did not observe the formation of any crystals. Which of the following statements best explains this observation?

choices.A: The temperature of the low-temperature bath was exactly the same as the mixture's freezing point.
choices.B: The temperature of the low-temperature bath was higher than the mixture's freezing point.
choices.C: The temperature of the low-temperature bath was lower than the mixture's freezing point.
choices.D: The mixture will not freeze and therefore has no freezing point.

questions.question: 23.  Based on the results of Experiment 2, why would it be better to use a mixture of antifreeze and H2O rather than pure H2O in a car radiator during hot weather? The mixture has a:

choices.A: higher boiling point than pure H2O.
choices.B: lower boiling point than pure H2O.
choices.C: higher freezing point than pure H2O.
choices.D: lower freezing point than pure H2O.

questions.question: 24.  Based on the passage and the results of Experiment 2, which of the following types of water would most likely have the lowest boiling point?

choices.A: Lake water
choices.B: Distilled water
choices.C: Salt water
choices.D: Tap water

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Heat conduction is a process by which heat is transferred from a region at a higher temperature to a region at a lower temperature. Two regions that are in thermal equilibrium with each other are at the same temperature. No heat is transferred between regions in thermal equilibrium with each other.

A student studied the relationship between the length and diameter of a copper wire connecting 2 metallic blocks and the rate of heat conduction between the blocks.

Experiment 1
A small aluminum block, A, was heated to 100℃ in boiling water, and an identical aluminum block, B, was cooled to 0℃ in ice water. Both blocks were immediately placed on an insulating surface (a surface that does not conduct heat well) and connected by a given length of 1 mm diameter copper wire initially at room temperature so that the wire would conduct heat from Block A to Block B (see Figure 1).


The temperature of each block was measured at regular time intervals for 3 minutes. The same procedure was done with different lengths of 1 mm diameter copper wire. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The procedure described in Experiment 1 was repeated using a copper wire with a diameter of 1.4 mm. The results are shown in Table 2.
questions.question: 25.  The best way to test the hypothesis that the rate of heat conduction depends on the type of wire material used in the experiments would be to repeat the experiments using:

choices.A: silver wires and aluminum wires differing in size from the copper wires.
choices.B: silver wires and aluminum wires having the same sizes as the copper wires.
choices.C: copper wires each having a different diameter.
choices.D: copper wires each having a different length.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:

Experiment 2

questions.question: 26.  During Experiments 1 and 2, the 2 blocks reached thermal equilibrium when which of the following copper wires was used?

choices.A: The 10 cm long, 1 mm diameter wire
choices.B: The 30 cm long, 1 mm diameter wire
choices.C: The 10 cm long, 1.4 mm diameter wire
choices.D: The 30 cm long, 1.4 mm diameter wire

questions.question: 28.  As thermal conductivity decreases, the ability to con-duct heat decreases. Brass has a thermal conductivity one-third that of copper. If, in any of the experiments, a copper wire were replaced with a brass wire of the same length and diameter, which of the following outcomes would be most likely?

choices.A: Block A would lose heat more slowly than when a copper wire was used.
choices.B: Block A would lose heat at the same rate as when a copper wire was used.
choices.C: Block B would gain heat at the same, rate as when a copper wire was used.
choices.D: Block B would gain heat more rapidly than when a copper wire was used.

questions.question: 29.  In each of the 2 experiments, the amount of heat lost by Block A was greater than the amount of heat gained by Block B. The most probable explanation for this inequality is that:

choices.A: Block A lost heat to the air.
choices.B: the copper wire lost heat to Block A.
choices.C: Block B lost heat to the copper wire.
choices.D: the air lost heat to Block B.

questions.question: 30.  Suppose, after 4 minutes, the temperature of Block A was 64°C and that of Block B was 23°C. According to the results of the experiments, which of the following copper wires was most likely being used to connect the blocks?

choices.A: A 1 mm diameter wire, 10 cm long
choices.B: A 1 mm diameter wire, 20 cm long
choices.C: A 1.4 mm diameter wire, 10 cm long
choices.D: A 1.4 mm diameter wire, 20 cm long

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Air at its dew point temperature (or dew point) is saturated with water vapor. Air temperature usually decreases with increasing altitude. When air cools to its dew point, the water vapor in the air can begin to condense and form clouds.

Air temperatures and dew points were measured every 600 m from the surface (0 m) to an altitude of 3,000 m at 4 cities (A-D). Data, including the altitude of the cloud base over each city, were taken at 2 P. M. on every summer day that clouds were present. Figures 1-4 show the average air temperatures, the average dew points, and the average cloud-base altitudes at each city.
questions.question: 31.  A pilot flying a plane at 1,200 m altitude notices that there are cloud layers.both above and below her, but none at her current altitude. Which of the following statements about the weather conditions at or near her altitude is supported by the information provided?

choices.A: The base of the upper cloud layer is at 600 m altitude and extends 1,200 m upward.
choices.B: The top of the lower cloud layer is at 1,202 m altitude.
choices.C: The air temperature is higher than the dew point at 1,200 m altitude.
choices.D: The dew point is above 80°F in both the upper and the lower cloud layers.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:

Figures 1-4 show the average air temperatures, the average dew points, and the average cloud-base altitudes at each city.
questions.question: 32.  A ceilometer bounces a light beam off the base of a cloud layer and measures how long it takes the light to make the trip up and back. The scientists who made the measurements plotted in Figures 1-4 most likely used the ceilometer to determine which of the following data?

choices.A: The average air temperature at the top of the cloud layers at Cities A-D
choices.B: The average dew point of the air at the top of the cloud layers at Cities A-D
choices.C: The average altitude of the bottom of the cloud layers at Cities A-D
choices.D: The average thickness of the cloud layers atCities A-D

choices.B: Air temperature: 36°F             Dew point: 36°F
choices.C: Air temperature: 38°F             Dew point: 45°F
choices.D: Air temperature: 45°F             Dew point: 45°F

questions.question: 34.  The table below shows the average July air temperatures and dew points at 0 m altitude for Miami, Florida, and for Phoenix, Arizona.Based on this information and the data in Figures 1-4, which of these 2 cities, on average, would have lower cloud bases in July?

choices.A: Phoenix, because it has a higher average air temperature than Miami.
choices.B: Phoenix; because the difference between the average air temperature and the average dew point is larger than in Miami.
choices.C: Miami, because it has a lower average air temperature than Phoenix.
choices.D: Miami, because the difference between the average air temperature and the average dew point is smaller than in Phoenix.

questions.question: 35. A certain city reported that the air temperature and the dew point at 0 m altitude measured at 8 A. M. on a given day were both 40°F. choices.A: 0 m

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
The amount of O2 present in blood and tissues can be measured, in mm Hg, as the partial pressure of O2 (). The percent saturation of Hb is the percent of hemoglobin in the blood that is bound with O2. Figure 1 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at normal body conditions.


Figure 2 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different pHs. The pH of blood is affected by the partial pressure of CO2 ().


Figure 3 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different blood temperatures.


Figures adapted from Robert Carola, John P. Harley, and Charles R. Noback, Human Anatomy and Physiology. ©1990 by McGraw-Hill, Inc.
questions.question: 36.  According to Figure 1, the greatest change in the percent saturation of Hb occurs within which of the following partial pressure ranges?

choices.A: 0 mm Hg to 10 mm Hg
choices.B: 20 mm Hg to 30 mm Hg
choices.C: 40 mm Hg to 50 mm Hg
choices.D: 60 mm Hg to 70 mm Hg

choices.A: Temperature = 10℃; pH = 7.6
choices.B: Temperature = 10℃; pH = 7.2
choices.C: Temperature = 43℃; pH = 7.6
choices.D: Temperature = 43℃; pH = 7.2

choices.B: No; as the temperature increased, the percent saturation of Hb decreased.

The amount of O2 present in blood and tissues can be measured, in mm Hg, as the partial pressure of O2 (). The percent saturation of Hb is the percent of hemoglobin in the blood that is bound with O2. Figure 1 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at normal body conditions.


Figure 2 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different pHs. The pH of blood is affected by the partial pressure of CO2 ().


Figure 3 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different blood temperatures.


Figures adapted from Robert Carola, John P. Harley, and Charles R. Noback, Human Anatomy and Physiology. ©1990 by McGraw-Hill, Inc.
questions.question: 39.  Which of the following tables represents the assumptions about temperature and pH that would have to be made to properly interpret the data in Figures 1-3?

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ

The amount of O2 present in blood and tissues can be measured, in mm Hg, as the partial pressure of O2 (). The percent saturation of Hb is the percent of hemoglobin in the blood that is bound with O2. Figure 1 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at normal body conditions.


Figure 2 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different pHs. The pH of blood is affected by the partial pressure of CO2 ().


Figure 3 shows the relationship between percent saturation of Hb and , at different blood temperatures.

questions.question: 40. Based on the data in Figure 2, which of the following statements best explains why  affects the pH of blood?  When CO2 dissolves in blood, it:

choices.A: forms an acid.
choices.B: absorbs acids.
choices.C: breaks down to form O2.
choices.D: reacts with O2 to form Hb.
